channel.title: The Subbuteo Argus
channel.description: The Subbuteo Argus is a weekly table football newsletter, covering table soccer news from FISTF-affiliated and WASPA-affiliated national associations.

item.title: IO Napoli title for Fiamme Azzurre
item.description:
Headlines

Fiamme Azzurre claim victory in Napoli

There’s been a curious lack of information published regarding this tournament so far, but it appears that Fiamme Azzurre Roma won the team event.

item.title: Four join Belgian Division 1
item.description:
Headlines

Four join Belgian Division 1

Michaël Casciano made a triumphant return to the top flight of the Belgian league last weekend, topping the qualification tournament table, with Philippe Roufosse (2nd), Geoffrey Marain (3rd), and Delphine Dieudonné (4th) joining him. The tournament, hosted by AS Hennuyer, saw 46 players compete for places in the Belgian Division 1, to be hosted in Eugies and Templeuve, along with a third venue which is yet to be decided.

item.title: Flores becomes World Champion
item.description:
Headlines

World Cup joy for Flores

Spanish player Carlos Flores stormed to victory in the FISTF World Cup last weekend, defeating Massimiliano Nastasi - himself a former champion - to lift the trophy for the third time to equal Massimo Bolognino’s record, whilst keeping the trophy in Spain for the fourth consecutive season. His 3-2 semi-final win against Daniele Bertelli was his lowest scoring game of the tournament, notching up a 45-17 goal difference over his 8 games, an astonishing 7.75 goals per match.

Spain dominant at World Cup

Spain put in a dominant performance at the World Cup, taking the Open and Under 19 category titles, along with the Open and Veteran team titles. Credit must surely go to Greek player Nikos Beis, whose 1-0 victory over Angel Valverde in the quarter final represented the only defeat of a player in the Spanish open team for the entire competition, as the side strolled to a 2-0 victory over Austria in the final. Google translate version

item.title: Dheur starts season with a bang
item.description:
Headlines

Dheur lifts first trophy of season in Belgium

Christophe Dheur’s season has started with a bang, lifting the first trophy of the 2015/16 season in Auvelais in the province of Namur in Belgium. The Belgian defeated Huynh Remy in the semi final, then went on to beat Benoit Massart in the final. The tournament also saw Vincent Coppenole take home the silverware in the ‘B’ category, whilst Dany Timmerman was victorious in the ‘C’ category. English translation

Articles

  • Austrian president Horst Deimel talks about the future of the game [de] (Google translate)

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • A preview of the event from the England camp
  • Preview of the World Cup in a Scottish newspaper
  • Programme of events for the tournament
  • Preview event at Centro Commeciale “Porto Grande” [it] (Google translate)

Mike Burns’ Italian Job

The Italian club league has become a major attraction over the last few years. What started with a a trickle of high profile signings, such as Carlos Flores’ move to Bologna Tigers, has become a torrent of transfers. But what has been the attraction?

Then based in Edinburgh, a combination of an ongoing dispute with his national association and a persuasive offer from his good friend Stefano De Francesco convinced Michael Burns to sign for the ACS Perugia. However, whilst he would be registered with the club under FISTF guidelines, in Italy he was set to play in Umbria TS - the club’s B team. At the time Umbria competed in the fourth tier of the Italian league. “Unfortunately I found out that Serie D was to be played in separate venue away from the big event itself and we had to qualify for Serie C”, says Mike. The club were league favourites, with De Francesco demanding promotion.

After signing for the club, his first appearance was at a ‘small’ regional tournament - “An event that over there wouldn’t be classed as a top event”, adds Mike. “The truth is, it was better than most Grand Prix I have attended “. Around 60 players representing 16 clubs attended the event, which was played using 20 identical boards, pitches, and goals. “It was unbelievable for what was supposedly a small event”.

Mike speaks glowingly about the game in Italy: “The organisation of the Italian Federation and how seriously all the players take the game is amazing”, he says, “Every player takes pride in their club and every club wants to improve and show off their ‘colours’. The team/club aspect is bigger than the individual game there, the way it should be”. For a long-time advocate of the team game in the UK, the appeal of that kind of atmosphere is clear. “It goes back to everyone taking pride in their club and their work which doesn’t really happen over here”.

The loyalty De Francesco inspired in the team is instantly apparent in the way that Burns talks: “Stefano spent a lot of time coaching the whole team, so it was imperative we won promotion for him”. They did, topping the Centro Sud division ahead of Fiamme Roma. The club also competed in the Coppa Italia, becoming the first Serie D side to make it past qualification. “40+ tables, 39 Open teams, 10 Junior teams and 2 U-19 teams - this is TEAMS, not individuals. Playing in that arena and seeing the whole set up is something to behold. There are so many players and the standard is so high you have no option but to play well or you will be put to the sword, you have to treat every player like they are Flores or Guimaraes and be switched on.”

Mike Burns’ one season experiment has quickly turned in to a two season experiment, and one that he feels could go on longer: “I really feel part of the club now and I am learning learning learning all the time, the standard of play is incredible and my ultimate goal I suppose really is to bring my experiences back to the UK and help get more clubs and players and get them playing to a high standard but also help out on the organisational side, not only am I learning a lot on the pitch but off it as well.”

item.title: Rouis showdown at French IO
item.description:
Headlines

Fayçal wins all-Rouis final at French IO

The French capital saw Fayçal Rouis defeat his brother, Mongi, 1-0 after extra time. It was by no means an easy passage for the Frenchman. Having scraped past Xavier Dubois in 1-0 the quarter finals, he also needed extra time to overcome Axel Donval 2-1 in the semis. Mark Offmann and Raphael Pommier won in the categories. English translation

Articles

  • Kind words for Subbuteo from the Italian Olympic Commitee [it] (Google translate)

Results, Reports, and Rankings

  • Cédric Garnier wins IO Yokohama
  • Giorgos Zangylos wins Cypriot Championship
  • 4th All-Ireland Championship win for Mark Farrell
  • Austrian Rankings for July 2015 [de] (Google translate)
  • Full results from the Helsinki IO
  • WASPA Circuit report for August 2015

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • Italian fencing champion to attend event [it] (Google translate)
  • USA, Japan, Wales, and Czech Republic to compete in warm up tournament [it] (Google translate)
  • Pro photographer to capture World Cup action [it] (Google translate)

Tartan Army on Tour Again

The forthcoming World Cup in San Benedetto will be the first World Cup held outside the UK since 2001 that has seen a Scottish team present. The team captain will be Mike Burns, who spent the last season at Italian club ACS Perugia following a dispute with the Scottish association. So why this year?

“Having played in every World Cup since 1998 I suppose it had lost a bit of its magic”, says Mike, “it was just another tournament on the calendar to go to”. Taking a line similar to the one Vasco Guimaraes had stated the month before, some of the blame for this was placed on the event being too regular, although he did add that there were a number of reasons why Scottish players haven’t ranked the event highly in recent years.

However, with changing circumstances for some of the Scottish squad, along with the opportunity for a holiday in the Italian sun, they have decided to attend. No doubt the choice has also been partially influenced by the possibility of five Hot Club d’Ecosse players being able to play together as a team again, the famous Edinburgh club having withdrawn from competition in their home nation.

But the big question is whether or not they’ll be wearing their iconic national dress: “As for our attire, we are getting some lovely new kits and it’s quite possible we’ll be voted the best dressed team”, beams Burnsie, “Kilts are optional - I have my own and might just take it …”

Treviso Satellite

Corrections

Last week’s issue places Guilio Astengo as the winner of the Yokohama IO, based on auto-translated reports from an Italian website. He was actually the winner of the veterans category, with Cédric Garnier defeating him in the Open category final.

item.title: Flickers Milano sweep up honours
item.description:
Headlines

Yokohama GP title for Astengo

Details are somewhat sparse, but Flickers Milano’s Giulio Astengo won the International Grand Prix of Japan in Yokohama last weekend, taking the Open trophy back to Italy, as well as reaching the final of the veteran category. English translation

Depascale crowned champion at Helsinki IO

Flickers Milano made it a double, with Vittorio Depascale defeating Australian ex-pat Bob Green in the final, followed by a win against Giorgos Papadopoulos the following day to bag the veteran title too. English translation

Australian Subbuteo

There’s been an abundance of news from down under this week, with five of the country’s six clubs hosting tournaments. Having renounced their full membership of FISTF in 2001, it had appeared that the Antipodean game was on it’s last legs, but a resurgence in recent years has seen the association go from strength to strength.

item.title: Honours for Walker and Cranston in Chicago
item.description:
Headlines

Honours go to Walker and Cranston in Chicago

Zach Walker & Daniel Cranston both left the windy city with silverware, with Walker taking home his seventh National Championship title, beating Paul Eyes 2-1 in the final. Walker beat Eyes again the following day in the semi-final of the International Open of Chicago, only to lose 2-1 to Daniel Cranston at the final hurdle. The was some consolation for the unfortunate Paul Eyes, however, as he became US Veteran National Champion with a 1-0 victory in the final, against Peter Alegi.

Murcilli wins International Open in Las Carolinas

Argentinian Claudio Murcilli topped a field of eight to take the first International Open to be staged in his home country after defeating Sebastian Pesci 2-1 in the final.

item.title: Scottish Cup joy for Christie
item.description:
Headlines

Christie lifts Scottish Cup

There was joy in Burntisland for Dundee United player Gareth Christie last weekend, as he beat Manchester TFC’s Malcolm Lees 2-0 in the final to lift the Scottish Cup, having defeated Andy Beskaby in the semi-finals. Lees himself had overcome strong opposition in the form of Dundee United’s Greg Dand and Glasgow’s Tom Burns, but fell short at the final hurdle.

Articles

  • How Subbuteo was introduced to Portugal [pt] (Google translate)
  • Juan Carlos Granados: Creator of Champions [it] (Google translate)
  • Video from the team final of the German GP
  • The return of Subbuteo Rugby [it] (Google translate)

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • Gala dinner announced
  • Full entry list revealed [es] (Google translate)
  • Maintaining World Class pitches [it] (Google translate)

The Argus: Volume 14

Volume 13 of The Argus will draw to a close at the end of this month, making way for the imaginatively titled ‘Volume 14’.

You may have noticed that there’s been a few interviews, and other articles, appearing over the past few weeks. The plan, along with a few visual tweaks to the design, is to include more articles in the newsletter:- expect features on the return of the Scottish national team to the World Cup, the Italian Club League, and an opinion piece on the future of the game in the UK to appear early on.

If you have any ideas for topics that could be covered, feel that you could provide an insight in to the game through an interview, have some news but nowhere to publish it, or would like to contribute a piece yourself, please get in touch by replying to this email. Anything Subbuteo-related will be considered!

item.title: Black & Blue Treble at Mattersburg Major
item.description:
Headlines

Victory for Pisa in Mattersburg Major

Black & Blue Pisa have continued their stellar season by lifting the team trophy, beating Fiamme Azzurre Roma 8-5 on goals scored in the final. The individual competition yielded another success for the Tuscans, with Daniele Bertelli defeating Catania IO winner Luca Colangelo 2-1 in the final, having defeated world champion Juan Noguera by the same score at the semi-final stage. Pisa also saw success in the veteran category, with Mauro Manganello taking the title. Google translate version

Articles

  • Video from the final of the German GP
  • LEGOalkeeper - make your own training aid out of Lego

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • Brazil names two man World Cup squad
  • Beer glasses added to array of World Cup merchandise [it] (Google translate)

Talking To Walker

This weekend, Zach Walker will attempt to equal Gregg Deinhart’s record of seven US National Championship titles, won between 1996 and 2004. Despite his impressive record, however, Walker feels that he’ll have his work cut out. He names US World Cup squad members Paul O’Donovan Rossa and Peter Alegi, former U19 champions Michael Tillman (2012) and Stuart Russell (2011), and home players Ilias Gikas and Erik Haefke amongst the strongest of the competition. And that’s before you get on to former national champions Daniel Cranston (2009, 2011) and Paul Eyes (2012)!

For a player who has seen so many top tournaments, you have to wonder which stick out as being the most memorable. “Certainly have been several”, comes the reply from the man from Colorado. It’s telling that, amongst the list of European Majors and FISTF World Cups come three tournaments closer to home; the 1999 and 2006 ASA National Championships, and the 2007 ASA Holiday Silver - the largest tournament ever held on American soil, attracting 66 players.

So what has he learnt in his 16 years at the top of the game? “Smile more while playing. I think you have to be serious and intense in this game in order to succeed, but having fun is the most important part”. Surely good advice for every player.

item.title: Mattersburg players dominate in German GP
item.description:
Headlines

Leitner takes honours in Bavaria

TFC Mattersburg’s Wolfgang Leitner won the German GP in Rain last weekend, defeating fellow Austrian Alexander Haas. The club also lifted the team trophy, comfortably beating Belgian side SC Stembert in the final, having dispatched fellow Austrians Wiener Neustadt at the semi-final stage. In the categories, World number 1 Gianfranco Calonico (Italy) won the veteran category, with Austrian youngsters Lukas Eppensteiner (Under 15) and Daniel Vranovitz (Under 12) won the junior categories, and home player Arnold Mair came out on top in the plate competition. Google translate version of main report

Excellent English GP for AS Hennuyer

75 players attended what must be seen as a warm-up for the FISTF Major to be held in England in 2016, with Belgian Under 19 star David Vantassel beating French AS Hennuyer teammate Remi Soret 2-1 after extra time in the final. With the veteran Belgian club providing both Open finalists, there was little shock when they also lifted the team competition, beating London & Essex United 3-1 in the final.

  • Japanese IO victory for Cédric Garnier
  • Loureiro is the toast of Porto

Articles

  • “Where are we playing?”: Australia’s first inter-club tournament
  • Nominations for 2015 FISTF Awards announced
  • Minutes from the French association’s AGM [fr] (Google translate)

ASA National Championships

This year sees the 25th anniversary of the American association’s national championships, to be hosted in Chicago on 8th/9th August. The first championships were first played in 1982, becoming an annual event ten years later. Some readers with longer memories might remember the last official “Subbuteo” World Cup - run by Waddingtons in 1994 - was held in the city, Belgian player Dominique De Marco defeating France’s Christophe Fuseau 4-3 in the final.

The tournament is to be hosted by Chicago United TSC, which has grown to become one of the largest clubs in the United States since the merger of Midwest United SC and the Chicago Area SC last December. Zach Walker will face stiff competition as he looks to equal Gregg Deinhart’s record 7 titles at the event. A short interview with the former English Premier League player will follow next week.
